conclusion: To determine the average velocities of Car A and Car B during the time interval from t = 0 to t = t1, we need to analyze the given velocity-time graphs.

The average velocity over a time interval can be calculated using the formula: Average velocity = Total displacement / Time interval. In a velocity-time graph, the total displacement is given by the area under the curve.
The graph shows two curves, one for Car A and one for Car B. Both curves start at v2 at t = 0 and end at v1 at t = t1.

premise: The area under the curve represents the total displacement of each car over the time interval.
conclusion: To compare the average velocities, we need to compare the areas under the curves for Car A and Car B from t = 0 to t = t1.
The second diagram overlays straight lines connecting (0, v2) to (t1, v1) for both cars.

premise: If the actual curves lie above these straight lines, the area under the curves will be greater than the area under the straight lines. If the actual curves lie below these straight lines, the area under the curves will be less than the area under the straight lines.
conclusion: The position of the curves relative to the straight lines affects the comparison of areas under the curves.
For Car A, the curve lies above the straight line connecting (0, v2) and (t1, v1). For Car B, the curve lies below the straight line connecting (0, v2) and (t1, v1).

premise: Since the area under the curve for Car A is greater than the area under the straight line and the area under the curve for Car B is less than the area under the straight line.
conclusion: The average velocity of Car A is greater than the average velocity of Car B.
